info.description: Functions and messages for collision object physics interaction with other objects (collisions and ray-casting) and control of physical behaviors.
info.name: Collision object

elements.description: The angular damping value for the collision object. Setting this value alters the damping of angular motion of the object (rotation). Valid values are between 0 (no damping) and 1 (full damping).
elements.examples:
How to decrease a collision object component's angular damping:

-- get angular damping from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "floater"
local target = "floater#collisionobject"
local damping = go.get(target, "angular_damping")
-- decrease it by 10%
go.set(target, "angular_damping", damping * 0.9)
elements.name: angular_damping

elements.description: READ ONLY Returns the current angular velocity of the collision object component as a vector3. The velocity is measured as a rotation around the vector with a speed equivalent to the vector length in radians/s.
elements.examples:
How to query a collision object component's angular velocity:

-- get angular velocity from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "boulder"
-- this is a 2d game so rotation around z is the only one available.
local velocity = go.get("boulder#collisionobject", "angular_velocity.z")
-- do something interesting
if velocity < 0 then
    -- clockwise rotation
    ...
else
    -- counter clockwise rotation
    ...
end
elements.name: angular_velocity

elements.description: Post this message to a collision-object-component to apply the specified force on the collision object. The collision object must be dynamic.

parameters.doc: vector3 the force to be applied on the collision object, measured in Newton
parameters.name: force

parameters.doc: vector3 the position where the force should be applied
parameters.name: position

elements.brief: applies a force on a collision object
elements.examples:
Assuming the instance of the script has a collision-object-component with id "co":

-- apply a force of 1 Newton towards world-x at the center of the game object instance
msg.post("#co", "apply_force", {force = vmath.vector3(1, 0, 0), position = go.get_world_position()})
elements.name: apply_force

elements.description:
This message is broadcasted to every component of an instance that has a collision object, when the collision object collides with another collision object. For a script to take action when such a collision happens, it should check for this message in its on_message callback function.

This message only reports that a collision actually happened and will only be sent once per colliding pair and frame. To retrieve more detailed information, check for the contact_point_response instead.

parameters.doc: hash the id of the instance the collision object collided with
parameters.name: other_id

parameters.doc: vector3 the world position of the instance the collision object collided with
parameters.name: other_position

parameters.doc: hash the collision group of the other collision object (hash)
parameters.name: other_group

parameters.doc: hash the collision group of the own collision object (hash)
parameters.name: own_group

elements.brief: reports a collision between two collision objects
elements.examples:
How to take action when a collision occurs:

function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the message
    if message_id == hash("collision_response") then
        -- take action
    end
end
elements.name: collision_response

elements.description:
This message is broadcasted to every component of an instance that has a collision object, when the collision object has contact points with respect to another collision object. For a script to take action when such contact points occur, it should check for this message in its on_message callback function.

Since multiple contact points can occur for two colliding objects, this message can be sent multiple times in the same frame for the same two colliding objects. To only be notified once when the collision occurs, check for the collision_response message instead.

parameters.doc: vector3 world position of the contact point
parameters.name: position

parameters.doc: vector3 normal in world space of the contact point, which points from the other object towards the current object
parameters.name: normal

parameters.doc: vector3 the relative velocity of the collision object as observed from the other object
parameters.name: relative_velocity

parameters.doc: number the penetration distance between the objects, which is always positive
parameters.name: distance

parameters.doc: number the impulse the contact resulted in
parameters.name: applied_impulse

parameters.doc: number life time of the contact, not currently used
parameters.name: life_time

parameters.doc: number the mass of the current collision object in kg
parameters.name: mass

parameters.doc: number the mass of the other collision object in kg
parameters.name: other_mass

parameters.doc: hash the id of the instance the collision object is in contact with
parameters.name: other_id

parameters.doc: vector3 the world position of the other collision object
parameters.name: other_position

parameters.doc: hash the collision group of the other collision object (hash)
parameters.name: other_group

parameters.doc: hash the collision group of the own collision object (hash)
parameters.name: own_group

elements.brief: reports a contact point between two collision objects
elements.examples:
How to take action when a contact point occurs:

function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the message
    if message_id == hash("contact_point_response") then
        -- take action
    end
end
elements.name: contact_point_response

elements.description: The linear damping value for the collision object. Setting this value alters the damping of linear motion of the object. Valid values are between 0 (no damping) and 1 (full damping).
elements.examples:
How to increase a collision object component's linear damping:

-- get linear damping from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "floater"
local target = "floater#collisionobject"
local damping = go.get(target, "linear_damping")
-- increase it by 10% if it's below 0.9
if damping <= 0.9 then
    go.set(target, "linear_damping", damping * 1.1)
end
elements.name: linear_damping

elements.description: READ ONLY Returns the current linear velocity of the collision object component as a vector3. The velocity is measured in units/s (pixels/s).
elements.examples:
How to query a collision object component's linear velocity:

-- get linear velocity from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "ship"
local source = "ship#collisionobject"
local velocity = go.get(source, "linear_velocity")
-- apply the velocity on target game object "boulder"'s collision object as a force
local target = "boulder#collisionobject"
local pos = go.get_position(target)
msg.post(target, "apply_force", { force = velocity, position = pos })
elements.name: linear_velocity

elements.description: READ ONLY Returns the defined physical mass of the collision object component as a number.
elements.examples:
How to query a collision object component's mass:

-- get mass from collision object component "boulder"
local mass = go.get("#boulder", "mass")
-- do something useful
assert(mass > 1)
elements.name: mass

elements.description: The following properties are available when connecting a joint of JOINT_TYPE_FIXED type:

parameters.doc: number The maximum length of the rope.
parameters.name: max_length

elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_FIXED

elements.description: The following properties are available when connecting a joint of JOINT_TYPE_HINGE type:

parameters.doc: number The bodyB angle minus bodyA angle in the reference state (radians).
parameters.name: reference_angle

parameters.doc: number The lower angle for the joint limit (radians).
parameters.name: lower_angle

parameters.doc: number The upper angle for the joint limit (radians).
parameters.name: upper_angle

parameters.doc: number The maximum motor torque used to achieve the desired motor speed. Usually in N-m.
parameters.name: max_motor_torque

parameters.doc: number The desired motor speed. Usually in radians per second.
parameters.name: motor_speed

parameters.doc: boolean A flag to enable joint limits.
parameters.name: enable_limit

parameters.doc: boolean A flag to enable the joint motor.
parameters.name: enable_motor

parameters.doc: number READ ONLYCurrent joint angle in radians. (Read only field, available from physics.get_joint_properties())
parameters.name: joint_angle

parameters.doc: number READ ONLYCurrent joint angle speed in radians per second. (Read only field, available from physics.get_joint_properties())
parameters.name: joint_speed

elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_HINGE

elements.description: The following properties are available when connecting a joint of JOINT_TYPE_SLIDER type:

parameters.doc: vector3 The local translation unit axis in bodyA.
parameters.name: local_axis_a

parameters.doc: number The constrained angle between the bodies: bodyB_angle - bodyA_angle.
parameters.name: reference_angle

parameters.doc: boolean Enable/disable the joint limit.
parameters.name: enable_limit

parameters.doc: number The lower translation limit, usually in meters.
parameters.name: lower_translation

parameters.doc: number The upper translation limit, usually in meters.
parameters.name: upper_translation

parameters.doc: boolean Enable/disable the joint motor.
parameters.name: enable_motor

parameters.doc: number The maximum motor torque, usually in N-m.
parameters.name: max_motor_force

parameters.doc: number The desired motor speed in radians per second.
parameters.name: motor_speed

parameters.doc: number READ ONLYCurrent joint translation, usually in meters. (Read only field, available from physics.get_joint_properties())
parameters.name: joint_translation

parameters.doc: number READ ONLYCurrent joint translation speed, usually in meters per second. (Read only field, available from physics.get_joint_properties())
parameters.name: joint_speed

elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_SLIDER

elements.description: The following properties are available when connecting a joint of JOINT_TYPE_SPRING type:

parameters.doc: number The natural length between the anchor points.
parameters.name: length

parameters.doc: number The mass-spring-damper frequency in Hertz. A value of 0 disables softness.
parameters.name: frequency

parameters.doc: number The damping ratio. 0 = no damping, 1 = critical damping.
parameters.name: damping

elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_SPRING

elements.description:
Create a physics joint between two collision object components.

Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.

parameters.doc: number the joint type
parameters.name: joint_type

parameters.doc: string | hash | url first collision object
parameters.name: collisionobject_a

parameters.doc: string | hash id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

parameters.doc: vector3 local position where to attach the joint on the first collision object
parameters.name: position_a

parameters.doc: string | hash | url second collision object
parameters.name: collisionobject_b

parameters.doc: vector3 local position where to attach the joint on the second collision object
parameters.name: position_b

parameters.doc:
table optional joint specific properties table

See each joint type for possible properties field. The one field that is accepted for all joint types is: - boolean collide_connected: Set this flag to true if the attached bodies should collide.
parameters.name: [properties]

elements.name: physics.create_joint

elements.description:
Destroy an already physics joint. The joint has to be created before a destroy can be issued.

Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.

parameters.doc: string | hash | url collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: string | hash id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

elements.name: physics.destroy_joint

elements.description:
Get the gravity in runtime. The gravity returned is not global, it will return the gravity for the collection that the function is called from.

Note: For 2D physics the z component will always be zero.
elements.examples:
function init(self)
    local gravity = physics.get_gravity()
    -- Inverse gravity!
    gravity = -gravity
    physics.set_gravity(gravity)
end
elements.name: physics.get_gravity

elements.description:
Get a table for properties for a connected joint. The joint has to be created before properties can be retrieved.

Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.

parameters.doc: string | hash | url collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: string | hash id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

returnvalues.doc:
properties table. See the joint types for what fields are available, the only field available for all types is:

  • boolean collide_connected: Set this flag to true if the attached bodies should collide.
returnvalues.name: [type:table]

elements.name: physics.get_joint_properties

elements.description:
Get the reaction force for a joint. The joint has to be created before the reaction force can be calculated.

Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.

parameters.doc: string | hash | url collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: string | hash id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

returnvalues.doc: vector3 reaction force for the joint
returnvalues.name: force

elements.brief: get the reaction force for a joint
elements.name: physics.get_joint_reaction_force

elements.description:
Get the reaction torque for a joint. The joint has to be created before the reaction torque can be calculated.

Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.

parameters.doc: string | hash | url collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: string | hash id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

returnvalues.doc: float the reaction torque on bodyB in N*m.
returnvalues.name: torque

elements.brief: get the reaction torque for a joint
elements.name: physics.get_joint_reaction_torque

elements.description: Ray casts are used to test for intersections against collision objects in the physics world. Collision objects of types kinematic, dynamic and static are tested against. Trigger objects do not intersect with ray casts. Which collision objects to hit is filtered by their collision groups and can be configured through groups.

parameters.doc: vector3 the world position of the start of the ray
parameters.name: from

parameters.doc: vector3 the world position of the end of the ray
parameters.name: to

parameters.doc: table a lua table containing the hashed groups for which to test collisions against
parameters.name: groups

returnvalues.doc: table It returns a table. If missed it returns nil. See ray_cast_response for details on the returned values.
returnvalues.name: result

elements.brief: requests a ray cast to be performed
elements.examples:
How to perform a ray cast synchronously:

function init(self)
    self.my_groups = {hash("my_group1"), hash("my_group2")}
end

function update(self, dt)
    -- request ray cast
    local result = physics.raycast(my_start, my_end, self.my_groups)
    if result ~= nil then
        -- act on the hit (see 'ray_cast_response')
    end
end
elements.name: physics.raycast

elements.description:
Ray casts are used to test for intersections against collision objects in the physics world. Collision objects of types kinematic, dynamic and static are tested against. Trigger objects do not intersect with ray casts. Which collision objects to hit is filtered by their collision groups and can be configured through groups. The actual ray cast will be performed during the physics-update.

  • If an object is hit, the result will be reported via a ray_cast_response message.
  • If there is no object hit, the result will be reported via a ray_cast_missed message.

parameters.doc: vector3 the world position of the start of the ray
parameters.name: from

parameters.doc: vector3 the world position of the end of the ray
parameters.name: to

parameters.doc: table a lua table containing the hashed groups for which to test collisions against
parameters.name: groups

parameters.doc: number a number between [0,-255]. It will be sent back in the response for identification, 0 by default
parameters.name: [request_id]

elements.brief: requests a ray cast to be performed
elements.examples:
How to perform a ray cast asynchronously:

function init(self)
    self.my_groups = {hash("my_group1"), hash("my_group2")}
end

function update(self, dt)
    -- request ray cast
    physics.raycast_async(my_start, my_end, self.my_groups)
end

function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the response
    if message_id == hash("ray_cast_response") then
        -- act on the hit
    elseif message_id == hash("ray_cast_missed") then
        -- act on the miss
    end
end
elements.name: physics.raycast_async

elements.description:
Set the gravity in runtime. The gravity change is not global, it will only affect the collection that the function is called from.

Note: For 2D physics the z component of the gravity vector will be ignored.

parameters.doc: vector3 the new gravity vector
parameters.name: gravity

elements.examples:
function init(self)
    -- Set "upside down" gravity for this collection.
    physics.set_gravity(vmath.vector3(0, 10.0, 0))
end
elements.name: physics.set_gravity

elements.description: Flips the collision shapes horizontally for a collision object

parameters.doc: string | hash | url the collision object that should flip its shapes
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: boolean true if the collision object should flip its shapes, false if not
parameters.name: flip

elements.brief: flip the geometry horizontally for a collision object
elements.examples:
function init(self)
    self.fliph = true -- set on some condition
    physics.set_hflip("#collisionobject", self.fliph)
end
elements.name: physics.set_hflip

elements.description:
Updates the properties for an already connected joint. The joint has to be created before properties can be changed.

Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.

parameters.doc: string | hash | url collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: string | hash id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

parameters.doc:
table joint specific properties table

Note: The collide_connected field cannot be updated/changed after a connection has been made.
parameters.name: properties

elements.name: physics.set_joint_properties

elements.description: Flips the collision shapes vertically for a collision object

parameters.doc: string | hash | url the collision object that should flip its shapes
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: boolean true if the collision object should flip its shapes, false if not
parameters.name: flip

elements.brief: flip the geometry vertically for a collision object
elements.examples:
function init(self)
    self.flipv = true -- set on some condition
    physics.set_vflip("#collisionobject", self.flipv)
end
elements.name: physics.set_vflip

elements.description: This message is sent back to the sender of a ray_cast_request, if the ray didn't hit any collision object. See physics.raycast_async for examples of how to use it.

parameters.doc: number id supplied when the ray cast was requested
parameters.name: request_id

elements.name: ray_cast_missed

elements.description: This message is sent back to the sender of a ray_cast_request, if the ray hit a collision object. See physics.raycast_async for examples of how to use it.

parameters.doc: number the fraction of the hit measured along the ray, where 0 is the start of the ray and 1 is the end
parameters.name: fraction

parameters.doc: vector3 the world position of the hit
parameters.name: position

parameters.doc: vector3 the normal of the surface of the collision object where it was hit
parameters.name: normal

parameters.doc: hash the instance id of the hit collision object
parameters.name: id

parameters.doc: hash the collision group of the hit collision object as a hashed name
parameters.name: group

parameters.doc: number id supplied when the ray cast was requested
parameters.name: request_id

elements.name: ray_cast_response

elements.description:
This message is broadcasted to every component of an instance that has a collision object, when the collision object interacts with another collision object and one of them is a trigger. For a script to take action when such an interaction happens, it should check for this message in its on_message callback function.

This message only reports that an interaction actually happened and will only be sent once per colliding pair and frame. To retrieve more detailed information, check for the contact_point_response instead.

parameters.doc: hash the id of the instance the collision object collided with (hash)
parameters.name: other_id

parameters.doc: boolean if the interaction was an entry or not
parameters.name: enter

parameters.doc: hash the collision group of the triggering collision object (hash)
parameters.name: other_group

parameters.doc: hash the collision group of the own collision object (hash)
parameters.name: own_group

elements.brief: reports interaction (enter/exit) between a trigger collision object and another collision object
elements.examples:
How to take action when a trigger interaction occurs:

function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the message
    if message_id == hash("trigger_response") then
        if message.enter then
            -- take action for entry
        else
            -- take action for exit
        end
    end
end
elements.name: trigger_response
